intro: Boswellia carteri, commonly known as frankincense, is a small, thorny shrub native to the dry regions of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It is characterized by its aromatic resinous sap, which is tapped from its bark and used in traditional medicine and incense. The plant belongs to the Burseraceae family and is known for its ability to thrive in arid and semi-arid environments. Its resin, called olibanum, has been used for centuries for its medicinal and aromatic properties. The botanical features of Boswellia carteri include its dense foliage, small leaves, and distinctive branching pattern.
